document.discussion_title: Tiffany Howard was one of five players with a hit Sunday. Ja
document.topic_text: Tiffany Howard was one of five players with a hit Sunday. Jay G. Tate/AuburnSports.com AUBURN | The Tigers' bats weren't much of a force Sunday, but they made their presence known at just the right time. Pitchers Lexi Davis and Rachael Walters handled the rest. Madi Gipson's RBI single tied the game during the sixth inning while Courtney Shea's RBI groundout moments later created all the scoring Auburn needed. The Tigers won 2-1 and earned a series sweep over Georgia. It's the team's fourth series sweep in a row against Southeastern Conference opponents. "It (was) a complete effort for us as far as what we needed to do," Auburn coach Clint Myers said. "If you keep (Georgia) off the bases, that limits their chances to score." The Bulldogs entered the weekend as the league's top hitting team, but they struggled to gain any advantages against Auburn's pitchers Sunday. Davis, who started the game, left a changeup down the middle for Georgia's Alyssa DiCarlo during the fourth inning. That mistake was deposited over the wall in left field. It was a jarring development for a game that had moved briskly to that point due to efficient pitching from both teams. Auburn watched a two-out rally stall during the fifth inning with Kasey Cooper on deck. That seemed like a missed opportunity. Still, Cooper led off the sixth with a walk. Then Carlee Wallace walked. After Jade Rhodes failed to get a bunt down, Madi Gipson cleaned up the mess with a single into the right-center gap. That allowed Cooper to score from second base. "I was just focusing on getting the ball on the ground," Gipson said. "I was ecstatic." The next hitter, Shea, grounded out to shortstop as pinch runner Bree Fornis scored from third base. That moved Auburn ahead 2-1 heading into the seventh inning. Walters dispatched the Bulldogs in order during that final inning to end the game. The senior's afternoon? Three innings pitched, zero hits allowed, zero runs allowed. "I really like high-pressure situations," Walters said. "That's what I really feed off of." Auburn (45-5, 14-4) resumes play next weekend with a series at Tennessee. Edit
